Issues.Title: fix(core): replace assertion with more intentional error
Issues.Body:
Issue #50320 shows that in some cases, updating a signal that's a dependency of a template during change detection of that template can have several adverse effects. This can happen, for example, if the signal is set during the lifecycle hook of a directive within the same template that reads the signal.

This can cause a few things to happen:

* Straightforwardly, it can cause `ExpressionChanged` errors.
* Surprisingly, it can cause an assertion within the `ReactiveLViewConsumer` to fail.
* Very surprisingly, it can cause change detection for an `OnPush` component to stop working.

The root cause of these later behaviors is subtle, and is ultimately a desync between the reactive graph and the view tree's notion of "dirty" for a given view. This will be fixed with further work planned for change detection to handle such updates directly. Until then, this commit improves the DX through two changes:

1. The mechanism of "committing" `ReactiveLViewConsumer`s to a view is changed to use the `consumerOnSignalRead` hook from the reactive graph. This prevents the situation which required the assertion in the first place.

2. A `console.warn` warning is added when a view is marked dirty via a signal while it's still executing.

The warning informs users that they're pushing data against the direction of change detection, risking `ExpressionChanged` or other issues. It's a warning and not an error because the check is overly broad and captures situations where the application would not actually break as a result, such as if a `computed` marked the template dirty but still returned the same value.

Issues.Title: Generate invalid factory for injectable in local compilation mode
Issues.Body:
Currently in local compilation mode the factory is generated by moving the type expression as they are into the inject functions. This disregards the case where the type is a type param:

```
@Injectable()
export class MainService<S> {
  constructor(private someService1: S ) {}
}
```
where symbol `S` will be undefined if moved as value to any function. Another example is type only import as directive ctor injection token:

```
import {type MyService} from './somewhere';

@Directive()
export class MyDirective {         
  constructor(private myService: MyService) {}  
}
```

This change takes care of these cases by generating invalid factory. This requires to move this logic into the reflection host as it is no longer possible to rely on its outputs which provides limited info for our purpose.

Issues.Body:
This PR adds code to use the performance.mark API to log usage of NgOptimizedImage, alongside existing DOM-based usage marker. The DOM-based marker will be removed at a future date.

Considerations:
**Is it a problem that this will get called multiple times if there are multiple NgOptimizedImage images instances on the page?** No--latter marks just overwrite the earlier ones and we only care about the presence or absence of this particular mark, not it's timing.

**Do we need to check for performance.mark() before it's called?** I checked around and I'm pretty sure no. It looks like performance.mark exists everywhere this code might be executed.

**Is there a way to test this?** I couldn't find one on short notice. This would have to be tested in e2e tests, and I haven't yet found a way to check for performance entries using Selenium. Would be happy to add a test if anyone has any input on this.

- Enabling resolving and loading of sourcemap in Node.js by using `process.setSourceMapsEnabled`. See https://nodejs.org/api/process.html#processsetsourcemapsenabledval

Issues.Title: bug(expansion-panel): `[style*=...]` attribute selector causes whole-page slowdown in Chromium
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

before #24045 (probably, I haven't tested it)

### Description

*Strictly speaking, [this is a Chromium bug](https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1364411), but (AFAICT) the only workaround is to change the CSS in the expansion panel component.*

Currently, in Chromium-based browsers, the presence of a CSS rule selector like `.blah[style*="something"] *` means that *any* change to the `style` attribute of **_any element, anywhere on the page_** will force a style recalculation of that element's entire subtree. There is currently a rule like this in `expanion-panel`:

https://github.com/angular/components/blob/52c85e55cd15d22abd02b4ff52b67c3752b2a27c/src/material/expansion/expansion-panel.scss#L78

Additionally, since `expanion-panel` has `ViewEncapsulation.None`, Angular won't limit the rule's scope using `[_nghost]`/`[_ngcontent]` attribute selectors, *and* Angular will copy the rule into any `ShadowDom`-encapsulated components.

https://github.com/angular/components/blob/52c85e55cd15d22abd02b4ff52b67c3752b2a27c/src/material/expansion/expansion-panel.ts#L82

###### *This issue was first noted [in this comment](https://github.com/angular/components/commit/c12347cafb18e900d19f613ce91afcca970d66d1#commitcomment-99447256).*

### Reproduction

StackBlitz link: https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-bsuofa?file=src%2Fapp%2Fexample-component.ts
#### Steps to reproduce:
1. Observe the animation is janky.

#### Proof that `expansion-panel` is responsible:
1. Delete the `<mat-expansion-panel>` element (and its children) from `example-component.html`.
2. Reload (to force Angular to clear unused component styles).
3. Observe the animation is now smooth.

#### Proof that the `[style]` selector is responsible:
1. Right-click > Inspect Element on "expanstion panel contents".
3. In DevTools, ensure that `<div class="mat-expansion-panel-body">` is selected.
4. (optionally) Record a performance trace and observe that "Recalculate Style" affects 10,001 elements and takes a long time.
5. Close the expansion panel.
6. In DevTools, edit the CSS selector `.mat-expansion-panel-content[style*="visibility: hidden"] *` to remove `[style*=...]`
7. Observe the animation is now smooth.
8. (optionally)  Record a performance trace and observe that "Recalculate Style" affects 1 element and is very fast.


### Expected Behavior

The animation is smooth regardless of if an expansion panel exists or what the expansion panel component does internally.

### Actual Behavior

The animation is smooth only after modifying an expansion-panel-internal CSS rule.

Issues.Title: feat(multiple): still support legacy components in v17
Issues.Body:
### Feature Description

In https://github.com/angular/components/pull/27622 you've removed support for legacy components. This means, that once Angular v17 is out, one would be forced to use the mdc-based components only.

While this might have been a reasonable choice for your team - also conforming to your update and deprecation policies - there are codebases out there (including ours) that haven't migrated to the new components yet.
Reasons for that are probably diverse, but one major reasons for us was the knowledge about your efforts on eventually offering a brand-new token-based theming API.

We work on a bigger enterprise grade application with a design system that's based on customized material components. Due to limited official support for customizations on the current theming API (as of v16 with legacy components) , we tend to override a lot of (global) component styles.
While eagerly waiting for the new token-based theming API to evolve and stabilize, we hoped to have the chance to upgrade directly to this new theming API, component by component.
With the discontinued support of legacy components in v17 however, this is now impossible and our migration path to the mdc-based components is very steep (either high effort or high risk).

### Use Case

I can only see 2 options for us to move forward right now:

1. While staying on v16, migrate each legacy component to the new mdc-based ones, component by component. This will require us to integrate with a new but still not latest theming API of the mdc-components first. After that migration is completed we would upgrade to v17 and have to re-integrate with the latest theming API once more, resulting in doubled theme integration effort. (high effort)
2. Upgrade to v17 and migrate to mdc-based components at the same time. This would require us to migrate all components at once, which would tremendously increase the risk of the migration. However, we would only need to integrate with the latest theming API once. (high risk)

Is there maybe another scenario that I am missing?

In case there's really no other option than these two, which I both consider as "not ideal", I would kindly ask you to re-consider still supporting legacy components in v17!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(multiple): still support legacy components in v17" (#27942)

Issues.Title: feat(MatSlider): Slider thumb value indicator should a popup
Issues.Body:
### Feature Description

The value indicator for the ```MatSliderThumb``` is currently part of the component template. This means that if the slider is used inside a component that has its ```overflow``` set to ```hidden``` (like inside a ```MatTab```) the value indicator gets cut off.

The value indicator should be a popup like the ```MatTooltip``` component so that it sits above the sliders containing element.

Currently a ```MatSlider``` with a value indicator is unusable inside a component like ```MatTab```.

### Use Case

The feature would enable using a ```MatSlider``` inside a ```MatTab``` component (or any container that hides its overflow) and not have the value indicator cut off.

Issues.Title: feat(material/theming): Add 'base' theming dimension to all components
Issues.Body:
Adds a `base` theming dimension to go along with `color`,`typography`, and `density`. The base dimension includes styles such as border-radiuses that do not vary with the chosen color, typography, or density, but may vary depending on the theming system (e.g. Material 2 vs Material 3).

BREAKING CHANGE:
There are new styles emitted by `mat.<component>-theme` that are not emitted by any of: `mat.<component>-color`, `mat.<component>-typography`, or `mat.<component>-density`. If you rely on the partial mixins only and don't call `mat.<component>-theme`, you can add `mat.<component>-base` to get the missing styles. Alternatively you can call `mat.all-component-bases` to get just the base styles for all components.
